Thanks for taking a look, Matei.  If we use system properties instead of env variables, the remaining reason we'd want to start a second JVM is to be able to have a --driver-memory property.  The only way around this I can think of would be to require users to set this with an environment variable instead of a command line option.  One small weird thing about this is that the client would still be given the max heap specified in driver SPARK_DRIVER_MEMORY even when the driver is being run on the cluster.
@pwendell Thanks, I have fixed style issues

Jenkins, retest this please

I think reduceByKeyToDriver is a better name and developer could easily figure out the behavior of this operation. Instead, reduceByKeyLocally is a little bit confusing, it looks like we only do reduceByKey on each machine and return a RDD. However, it actually sends a Map to driver. I feel we should deprecate reduceByKeyLocally instead, my two cents.
I think I've covered all the formatting requests. Any other issues?

I played around with these and it looks good to me. Thanks!

Hi Sandy,
What is the point to give a new name to "yarn-standalone" ? I think it requires people to change their spark code build for yarn and create some confusions. The bottom line, I think we want to have a identify for each mode and these identifies should not be changed very frequently.
-Shengzhe

@manishamde Do you mind updating the code style first to make it easy for people who want to review the code? I will mark a few examples. We also need a Spark JIRA ticket for this PR.

@etrain It would be great if the optimization you mentioned is documented somewhere in the code or in the guide. It helps understand the code and the comments here will be ignored after this PR gets merged.

@yaoshengzhe this supports "yarn-standalone" for backwards compatibility so you don't need to change your application. The name "yarn-standalone" is really confusing because the other resource manager is called "standalone mode" and it's different than YARN. This is a big enough issue that it warrants changing before the 1.0 release, especially given that we support the old name.
@sryza thanks Sandy this looks good to me. @tgraves want to take a look? If not I can merge this tonight - it's just some doc fixes.

I uploaded a new patch that takes most of the review feedback into account.  Includes the following changes:
- changes Opt to OptionAssigner and uses default parameters
- makes deployMode a boolean instead of an int
- renames to spark-submit
- adds (and takes advantage of) system properties for the yarn-client configs that can be used instead of env vars
- removes --client-classpath
- marks helper classes as private

I still need to tidy up the usage string.  And there's the outstanding question of whether we can avoid starting a new JVM.
@pwendell I agree what you saying. One more question, is that possible to move all these string constants in some class ?
Looks good to me (with the doc fixes commented on).

Hey @tgravescs this looks good to me. Is there anything else you'd like to address before merging this? If not, feel free to merge it into master.

I think it would be good if the persisted UI noted somewhere that the associated application is dead -- maybe you could add this in ui/UIUtils.scala, in the header that currently says "application UI" (thoughts @pwendell ?)
LGTM, except the extra empty line. Do you mind creating a Spark JIRA for this PR?

I see, regarding the memory part, it sounds like we could do it in bash, but it might be kind of painful. We could do the following:
- Look for just the driver memory and cluster mode arguments using bash
- If we're not running in cluster mode, set the -Xmx and -Xms parameters when launching

I agree that we shouldn't use the full memory you required if you submitted to a cluster. I'm not sure how hard it is to parse these arguments in bash -- it shouldn't be _that_ hard, but we'll also have to do it in .cmd scripts on Windows and such. Otherwise It would be good to test how slow this is with two JVM launches (maybe we can avoid a lot of the slowness).
Jenkins, add to whitelist and test this please

hey @tgravescs good catch on this one.

In terms of abstracting. The most abstract we could do would be to add a method to a `Partition` called `getPipeEnvVars` or something. That seems maybe a bit heavyweight since this is just, for now, a single case. An intermediate thing would be to add `getPipeEnvVars` only to `HadoopPartition` and move the logic about input split checking to HadoopPartition. That seems slightly nicer to me and it would leave the door open to bumping that method into the `Partition` class. What do you think about that? This is just an idea not really a strong preference.

Small comment about the tests.
That is Jenkins complaining about the style BTW, hopefully should be easy to fix. You can run sbt/sbt scalastyle to run the same tests locally.
Thanks @kellrott for this patch - sorry it took us a long time to review it. I'm going to merge this now.
I've created SPARK-1201 (https://spark-project.atlassian.net/browse/SPARK-1201) to cover optimizations in cases other than DISK_ONLY.
Jenkins, test this please.
Adding a routine to HadoopPartition sounds good.
@ankurdave does this look okay to you?
Looks good. Thanks!

Cell : 425-233-8271

Hey @sryza I tested this using a local standalone cluster and it didn't seem to work. The executors failed when they were asked to launch pyspark:

```
14/03/06 15:50:56 INFO Executor: Running task ID 1
14/03/06 15:50:56 INFO Executor: Running task ID 2
/usr/bin/python: No module named pyspark
14/03/06 15:50:57 ERROR Executor: Exception in task ID 3
java.io.EOFException
        at java.io.DataInputStream.readInt(DataInputStream.java:392)
        at org.apache.spark.api.python.PythonWorkerFactory.startDaemon(PythonWorkerFactory.scala:177)
        at org.apache.spark.api.python.PythonWorkerFactory.createThroughDaemon(PythonWorkerFactory.scala:55)
        at org.apache.spark.api.python.PythonWorkerFactory.create(PythonWorkerFactory.scala:42)
        at org.apache.spark.SparkEnv.createPythonWorker(SparkEnv.scala:88)
        at org.apache.spark.api.python.PythonRDD.compute(PythonRDD.scala:53)
        at org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD.computeOrReadCheckpoint(RDD.scala:239)
        at org.apache.spark.rdd.RDD.iterator(RDD.scala:230)
        at org.apache.spark.scheduler.ResultTask.runTask(ResultTask.scala:111)
```

Here is what I ran:

```
./bin/spark-class org.apache.spark.deploy.master.Master
./bin/spark-class org.apache.spark.deploy.worker.Worker <master url>
MASTER=<master url> ./bin/pyspark
>>> sc.parallelize(range(1000), 10).count()
```
You need to run make inside the python directory first.  Did you do that?  (This obviously needs to be documented).
